title: 104_hr1282
content:
The "Neighborhood Infrastructure Improvement and Inner City Job Creation Act" establishes a grant program for eligible administrative entities to provide employment opportunities through community facility repair and renovation. The grant program under the "Neighborhood Infrastructure Improvement and Inner City Job Creation Act" is available to administrative entities like private industry councils, local governments, nonprofit organizations, and Native American tribes serving areas with a poverty rate exceeding 30 percent. The grant program prioritizes administrative entities with populations of 50,000 or more or Native American tribes on reservations, giving priority to low-skilled workers in program participation. SEC. 4. APPLICATION. The Secretary requires eligible administrative entities to submit an application for grants under section 2. SEC. 5. USE OF AMOUNTS. The Secretary may grant funds to eligible administrative entities for programs employing individuals to repair community facilities like bridges, public buildings, housing units, water systems, and traffic signs. The Secretary may grant funds for repairing community facilities such as bridges, public buildings, housing units, water systems, and traffic signs. The funds can be used for various purposes including removing road sign obstructions, replacing road surface markings, repairing roads and streets, renovating parks and playgrounds, installing drainage pipes, ramps for individuals with disabilities, and weatherizing community facilities. Additionally, up to 25 percent of the grant amount can be used for administrative costs and acquiring supplies and equipment. SEC. 6. ELIGIBLE INDIVIDUALS. Eligibility requirements for participation in the program described in section 5(a) include being unemployed, having been unemployed for at least 15 weeks prior to enrollment, making a good-faith attempt to find employment, and for secondary school-age individuals, not attending secondary school for the 6-month period before enrollment. Priority for participation in the program is given to individuals who have exhausted or are ineligible for unemployment benefits, especially those who have been unemployed for a long time before selection. SEC. 7. NONDISCRIMINATION.

No individual shall be excluded from participation in, denied benefits, or discriminated against in any program under section 5(a) based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age, disability, or political affiliation.

SEC. 8. LABOR STANDARDS.

Labor standards from the Job Training Partnership Act apply to programs under section 5(a).

SEC. 9. MAINTENANCE OF EXPENDITURES. SEC. 9. MAINTENANCE OF EXPENDITURES.

The Secretary may not grant funds to an eligible entity unless it agrees to maintain its spending levels for facility repairs and renovations. SEC. 11. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $1,000,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1996 for section 2, with additional funds as needed for each following year. Appropriated funds will remain available until expended.
